Therefore, it is said that the monk Punggisha was able to compose verses. This monk, when he was previously the son of an elder, was a person with a brilliant and sharp mind who praised things upon contact.

The skills I have learned are complete. I can now give her to you.

At that time, it was the right time for the festival, and the king gathered all the skilled performers to try out their artistic skills. If the best one was found, he would be given a thousand taels of gold.
The king also heard that this girl was wonderful and wanted to take her into the palace.
The test of skills was to climb the flagpole.
The flagpole was forty-nine feet high, with swords and knives placed below, all pointing upwards, with space for the feet in between.
At that time, Pung-gyu climbed the flagpole, circled seven times in the air, and then descended to the open ground.
The king feared losing the girl and pretended not to watch.
Everyone said she was wonderful.
The king said:
I do not see it.
If you are sure it is wonderful, then do it again.
Pung-gyi thought to himself:
If I do not follow the king's order, I will surely lose this woman, and my plan will be ruined.
Pung-gyi risked his life to try again. When he reached the top of the pole, he looked at the woman's face and thought to himself:
Why is this person sitting here to the point of exhaustion?
He was afraid and trembling, fearing he would not be able to save himself:
What use is this woman's false pretense?
The Buddha knew that this person could definitely be saved, and if he was not rescued, he would fall into the three evil paths.
He told MaudgalyÄyana:
Use your spiritual powers to save him from this danger.

MaudgalyÄyana accepted the teaching and immediately went to manifest a transformation. He sat in full lotus posture in the sky, and below the pole he manifested a staircase of the seven treasures. The others did not see it, only Pung-gyi saw it.
He slowly descended the staircase seven times, and due to the spiritual power of MaudgalyÄyana, he was safe inside but in danger outside.
The king and the people were greatly astonished. The king personally pulled the girl and handed her over to Pung-gyo.
Pung-gyo said:
I do not need this deceitful thing to deceive the world and confuse the pure and honest. The destruction of the country and the breaking up of the family are all due to this.
He then followed MaudgalyÄyana and went to the World-Honored One.
The World-Honored One said:
Welcome, bhiká¹£u!

Protecting the Å›rÄvakas, with the three insights destroying the nature of bonds.

For this reason, it is said that PÅ«rá¹‡a is the foremost in composing verses and praising the TathÄgata's virtues.ğŸ”½As for why it is said that Kauá¹£á¹­hila is foremost in the four eloquences, the four eloquences of ordinary Å›rÄvakas are not necessarily complete. The reason why the bhiká¹£u NandÄ« is called the foremost in begging for food is that although other bhiká¹£us also beg for food, some do not fully observe the precepts, some have greedy minds, some look around without focusing their minds, and some avoid cold and heat.

Now, a metaphor is used to illustrate the great and small.
Someone asked about archery:
One person shoots a hundred steps and hits a fine hair, while another shoots at dust on the ground.

The field of merit is thick, so there is no increase or decrease; the ascetic practice is refined or coarse, so there is success and failure.
Nandi obtained the refined, so he is called the first.
The reason for calling it one sitting and one meal is that this refers to one practice of austerity.
The ascetic practice is either begging for food, or sitting under a tree, or living alone in seclusion.
Now, this one sitting and one meal means from early morning until noon, if a layperson offers food, regardless of the amount, one sits and eats in one place.
If one has not yet finished eating and has not moved from one's seat, one may eat more; if one has already gotten up, one may not eat again.
He always ate in one place and did not leave, so he was called ÅšrÄ«gupta as the foremost.
As for the bhiká¹£u Jyotiá¹£ka, he always begged for alms from seven families and did not go beyond seven.
The reason for this is that he made a vow to limit himself to seven.

When begging for food, he wished to benefit and deliver sentient beings, single-mindedly contemplating the Way without any greedy thoughts. Whether he obtained good or bad food, he did not increase or decrease [his begging], but begged for food in order, not choosing between poor and rich.
If he obtained food at one or two families, and there were more donors, he would stop if full, and if not full, he would accept more.

If he reached seven families and did not obtain food, he would then return to his dwelling place and contemplate practicing the Way, not thinking about going to a certain family tomorrow or not going to a certain family, having no discriminating thoughts at all. The practice of the bhiká¹£u Sthiramati was to always dwell in secluded places in the mountains and fields. The practice of the bhiká¹£u Nandika was to endure humiliation by begging for food. Other bhiká¹£us extinguished their bonds and then penetrated emptiness. The mind of emptiness is difficult to attain.
Valuing his prior attainment, he was called the best.

The reason for calling the bhiká¹£u Nipo who took the five robes as supreme is that this bhiká¹£u contemplated the body's impurities and thirty-six substances, nothing to be coveted or valued, and thus disgusted with this body, he used lowly things to cover himself.

Or if in the animal realm, constantly eating grass and thorns, this too has passed;
If one is in the realm of hungry ghosts, molten copper is one's food, or if one is in the hells, swords and staves are one's companions. All these forms of suffering are due to one's past.

Now that one has obtained a human body, this is the end of that retribution. What is valued in ancient and modern times are all discarded objects, illusory and precarious forms, not one is worth coveting, all should be abandoned.
So he stayed at the charnel ground and thought again:

Therefore, he is called the foremost among the bhiká¹£us who do not speak to people and walk while looking at the ground. This bhiká¹£u always suffered from verbal faults. He was about to reform them and thought to himself:
